awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  A cost-effective means of culturing large volumes of microalgae for land-based oyster farming.
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to improve shellfish production at scale and in an environmentally sustainable fashion, using oyster farming as a launching pad.  Today, most oysters are farmed nearshore under ecological stress.  This project advances the culturing of microalgae using internal waste streams and those from other food industries. The focus of this project is to process one of the most abundant, sustainable, and freely available industrial food wastes, spent yeast from breweries, to facilitate algae production at scale onshore and indoors. Although currently used primarily by the food and chemical industries, the less costly algal product could also energize areas of food and feed, nutraceuticals, pharmaceuticals, biofuels, biomaterials, and bioremediation services.

The proposed project will advance the use of off-the-shelf bioreactors and a novel substrate which, along with CO2, form plant tissue heterotrophically in the dark as leaves do photosynthetically in the presence of sunlight. The proposed substrate enables production at scale of the single-celled microalgae that comprise much of the nearshore bivalve diet.  The yeast is fermented with both agriculture-grade vitamins and plant-based commodities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Outcome Report

This report serves as a summary, prepared specifically for the public, of the nature and outcomes of the project. This report will be posted on the NSF website exactly as it is submitted by the PI.

 

NSF STTR  Phase I

Award Number:2112253

 

Project Title: STTR Phase I: A cost-effective means of culturing large volumes of microalgae for land-based oyster farming

Project Outcome

Maine Selfish Developers LLC

  1.  Concept:  The overarching goal of this NSF STTR Phase I research was to find a way to reduce the cost of culturing microalgae for shellfish aquaculture. Were that possible, certain intertidal bivalves, including oysters, clams and mussels, could be farmed on-land and indoors in vast numbers sustainably and affordably anywhere. 

 

  1.  Essential Technologies: Surprisingly, only five technologies are required to achieve what has been long overdue, the expansion of the oyster industry landward, hence free of both regulatory and ecological limitations. The five technologies are: a) a shellfish-specific means of cleansing recycling wastewater; b) eschewing deep, circular tanks in favor of stacking fiberglass raceways; C) devising an abundant, but cost-effective feed; d) utilizing a high level of automation; and e) installing computerized processing and packaging equipment.

 

  1.  Collaborative Research: Oyster hatchery operators sell their seed no larger than a quarter inch because of the high costs of culturing microalgae to feed them if held longer. However, market-size is 3.0” or 12 times  larger and, although microalgae are the best oyster feed, they are unacceptably expensive. In fact,  it is the cost of  culturing the media  or “fertilizer” that is the driver. Yet culturing microalgae on a less expensive media has eluded investigators for years.

 

Fortuitously, MSD could turn to the nearby Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences and Dr Michael Lomas, Director of its Center for Algal Innovations (CAI). Would it be possible to derive a cost-effective medium from freely available industrial food waste?  He thought it was, so MSD/CAI applied for and were awarded this NSF STTR Phase I grant. Within a year CAI staff had five strains of algae commonly used in hatcheries growing on media derived from a certain industrial food waste.

Subsequent, oyster feed trials were scheduled  utilizing those five strains. This breakthrough portends cost effective microalgae cultivation for shellfish purposes and much more.

                                  ,                                                                                                           

  1.  Broad Impact: The outcome of the Phase II R&D to follow these Phase I results will make possible two significant food security advances. They are closed containment shellfish farming and the more rapid integration  of microalgae as a major component in human food and animal feed systems. Microalgae have eight times protein than rice per weight and as much as soy, but unlike rice, soy, corn and wheat, microalgae have ample omega-3 fatty acids, and more. That an inexpensive media can enable so much is impressive and welcomed.

 


Last Modified: 06/27/2023
Modified by: Taylor A Pryor

Project Outcome

Maine Selfish Developers LLC

 Concept:  The overarching goal of this NSF STTR Phase I research was to find a way to reduce the cost of culturing microalgae for shellfish aquaculture. Were that possible, certain intertidal bivalves, including oysters, clams and mussels, could be farmed on-land and indoors in vast numbers sustainably and affordably anywhere.

Fortuitously, MSD could turn to the nearby Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences and Dr Michael Lomas, Director of its Center for Algal Innovations (CAI).  Broad Impact: The outcome of the Phase II R&D to follow these Phase I results will make possible two significant food security advances. That an inexpensive media can enable so much is impressive and welcomed.
